coredata.dc:title: Gradient SEI layer induced by liquid alloy electrolyte additive for high rate lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Xu, Weina
Liao, Xiaobin
Xu, Wangwang
Sun, Congli
Zhao, Kangning
Zhao, Yan
Hu, Chenguo
coredata.dc:description: Current energy storage device has fallen short behind from the fast growing requirement for (hybrid) electric vehicles and portable devices including mobile phones, which drives the lithium metal anode to be a research hot topic. However, the large volume change of lithium metal anode induces instable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer, which prevents its further development. A stable SEI layer required flexible surface to accommodate the large volume variation and inorganic core with low Li+ partial molar volume for dendrite suppression. Herein, we achieved a gradient SEI which is composed of flexible surface-rich polycarbonate moieties and low Li+ partial molar volume inorganic LiF-rich core by applying liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive. Initially, the calculation verified that liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive would facilitate the initial decomposition of LiPF6, and lead to the formation of the gradient SEI layer. In the Li||Li half‐cell test, we successfully achieved dense deposition of Li metal and in this way, the cycling performance with liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive is greatly improved especially at high rate (10 mA cm−2). Voltage polarization was greatly reduced and Coulombic efficiency was effectively improved due to the gradient SEI layer achieved in the interface of Li anode and electrolyte. In the Li||LFP cell, high average coulombic efficiency (99.06%) at long cycle life (＞2500 cycles) is achieved for the liquid alloy GaSnIn‐protected Li metal anode at high areal capacity (3 mAh/cm2). These results deepen our understanding on liquid alloy as a promising electrolyte additive for efficient dendrite suppressing, enabling the practical lithium metal batteries (LMBs).
coredata.dcterms:subject: Lithium metal
Liquid alloy
Electrolyte additive
Gradient SEI layer

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Decomposition timeline for degradation of EC and LiPF6 at the Li metal surface with and without liquid alloy GaSnIn. (b) Molecular structure and visual electrostatic potential isosurfaces of EC, DEC, and PF6 –. (c, d) Side view of the final configurations showing the complete simulation cell if the Li metal surface with and without liquid alloy GaSnIn, respectively. The left image displays the atomic density profile corresponding to the Li metal surface with and without liquid alloy GaSnIn. The right is the line profile of planar average potential from lithium metal surface to the interface.

Voltage-time curves of Li plating process in (a) LiPF6-EC/DMC and (b) LiPF6-EC/DMC-GaSnIn electrolyte at 1 mA cm−2. (c) Rate capability of Li||Li cells in pristine electrolyte and electrolyte with GaSnIn electrolyte additive at different current. Cycling stability of Li||Li cells in pristine electrolyte and electrolyte with GaSnIn electrolyte additive at (d) 1 and (e) 5 mA cm−2, respectively. Insets show the magnified view of the cycling performance at 0–15 and 240–255 h.

Side views SEM images of lithium metal plate in electrolyte (a–d) with and (e–h) without GaSnIn electrolyte additive at different cycling time (2, 10, 100 and 250 h) in Li||Li cells. Scale bars: 50 µm. Top views SEM images of lithium metal plate (i) in pristine electrolyte and (j) electrolyte with GaSnIn electrolyte additive. Scale bars: 1 µm. (k, l) Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the Li||Li cells in pristine electrolyte and electrolyte with GaSnIn electrolyte additive before and after cycling.
Depth profile XPS spectra of (a) F 1s, (b) Ga 3d, (c) C 1s, and (d) Li 1s of Li||Li cells after cycling in electrolyte with GaSnIn electrolyte additive.

(a) Cycle performance and (b) the corresponding coulombic efficiency of the Li||LFP full cells in pristine electrolyte and electrolyte with GaSnIn electrolyte additive. The charge-discharge curves of the Li||LFP full cells in (c) electrolyte with GaSnIn electrolyte additive and (d) pristine electrolyte in the first few cycles.

head.ce:title: Gradient SEI layer induced by liquid alloy electrolyte additive for high rate lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Current energy storage device has fallen short behind from the fast growing requirement for (hybrid) electric vehicles and portable devices including mobile phones, which drives the lithium metal anode to be a research hot topic. However, the large volume change of lithium metal anode induces instable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer, which prevents its further development. A stable SEI layer required flexible surface to accommodate the large volume variation and inorganic core with low Li+ partial molar volume for dendrite suppression. Herein, we achieved a gradient SEI which is composed of flexible surface-rich polycarbonate moieties and low Li+ partial molar volume inorganic LiF-rich core by applying liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive. Initially, the calculation verified that liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive would facilitate the initial decomposition of LiPF6, and lead to the formation of the gradient SEI layer. In the Li||Li half‐cell test, we successfully achieved dense deposition of Li metal and in this way, the cycling performance with liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive is greatly improved especially at high rate (10 mA cm−2). Voltage polarization was greatly reduced and Coulombic efficiency was effectively improved due to the gradient SEI layer achieved in the interface of Li anode and electrolyte. In the Li||LFP cell, high average coulombic efficiency (99.06%) at long cycle life (＞2500 cycles) is achieved for the liquid alloy GaSnIn‐protected Li metal anode at high areal capacity (3 mAh/cm2). These results deepen our understanding on liquid alloy as a promising electrolyte additive for efficient dendrite suppressing, enabling the practical lithium metal batteries (LMBs).

ce:section.ce:para: With growing impact of lithium ion battery in portable electronic devices as well as (hybrid) electric vehicles, current lithium ion battery configuration based on LiCoO2 and graphite are falling short of the goal of higher energy density (500 Wh/kg) based on the projection of Department of Energy in United States [1–4]. To further improve the energy density, replacing the current anode (graphite) with the lithium metal possibly lead to doubled energy density, due to the most electronegative potential and larger capacity (3860 mAh g−1) than those of graphite anodes [5,6]. However, Li metal is highly active and would reduce all the organic electrolytes studied, leading to severe dendrites formation, resulting in low coulombic efficiency (CE), fast capacity fading as well as the crossover of lithium dendrites for cell short circuit, which, in all, hinders the practical application of lithium metal battery (LMB), especially in electric vehicles [7,8].

The highly reactive Li metal would reduce the commercialized carbonate electrolytes when immersed in, facilitating the formation of homogeneous organic‐inorganic solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) to protect the electrode from the electrolyte attacking. However, during the repeated Li plating/stripping, there will be large volume variation, leading to the non-uniform and excessive SEI cracking and regeneration, which in turn would facilitate the Li dendrite formation. In this regard, building a robust and flexible SEI layer, to adjust to the repeated volume changes, while maintaining good lithium conductivity, would be crucial for the application of lithium metal battery. Current researchers have achieved great success in applying the high mechanical flexibility polymer to relieve the repeated volume variations during repeated Li plating/stripping [9–11]. However, polymer based SEI layer would set up an intimate bonding between SEI layer and lithium metal, and in this way, the SEI layer would be unable to suffer from the repeated volume changes and finally, the cracking of the SEI layer would be unavoidable. This dendritic growth is due to low interfacial energy of the SEI, leading to the preferable growth of lithium in one direction. Inorganic lithium compounds (such as LiF, Li2O, Li3N, etc.) with a high interfacial energy and weak bonding with Li metal is believed to boost the Li lateral diffusion along the SEI/Li interface and suppress metallic Li from penetrating into the inorganic SEI. Meanwhile, the ceramic SEI with a high Young's modulus is also mechanically strong for better suppression of dendritic growth and penetration of the interface [12,13]. Tuning the electrolyte would vary the composition of the SEI layer between lithium metal and electrolyte, by tailoring interfacial electrolyte environment [14–18]. Carbonate electrolyte has been most widely applied as commercialized electrolyte since its good compatibility of the current commercialized anode, graphite by forming stable bonding and accommodating the small volume variations. However, Li metal anode would induce much greater volume variations and the SEI layer induced by current carbonate electrolyte is unable to sustain the flexibility to accommodate the large volume variations. Various electrolyte additives have been widely explored to tune the composition of the SEI composition [19,20]. Among those, fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) and vinylene carbonate (VC) are demonstrated to be quite successful in stabilizing the SEI layer through facilitating the formation of inorganic LiF and Li2CO3 components in the SEI [21]. LiF with low Li+ diffusion barrier and large bandgap (13.6 eV), is able to enhance the lithium ion transport kinetics and as insulator, reject the electrons from passing through SEI layer and suppress the side reaction of electrolyte decomposition [22–25]. More recently, Shadike et al. for the first time reported that LiF in the SEI is found to have different structural features from LiF in the bulk phase, which favor Li+ transport [26]. However, the inferior adsorption energy of LiF with Li+ hinders its sole application for SEI protective layer. The strong affinition of polymer with lithium metal would be far from enough to adjust to the large volume changes of lithium metal anode. Therefore, creating a gradient SEI layer with highly conductive inorganic component rich inside and flexible organic component outside would combine both advantages of flexible polymer in the surface and LiF rich inside to suppress dendrite formation, but would be of great challenge.

Previous study suggested that introducing the liquid alloy in the interface between lithium metal and electrolyte would result in the high deformability, and self-healing, which are favorable for continuous and reversible interactions between Ga and plated Li [27]. Among those liquid alloy, Ga-based LM not only displays a low melting point but also is quite low in toxicity due to the fact that Ga essentially has no vapor pressure at room temperature (<10−6 Pa at 500 °C)[28]. Metal atoms in liquid metals can possess high mobility, resulting in fluidic and metallic properties of liquid metals. Ga has been reported to quickly diffuse and embrittle high-melting metals in contact regions, indicating its great potential in reacting with Li dendrites and once the delithiation process begins, the liquid surface of Ga is completely recovered based on its self-healing nature[27]. However, during the lithiation state, Li-Ga alloy would be solid state rather than liquid state. In this sense, the Ga based liquid alloy is not sufficient to stabilize the lithium metal, especially at lithium rich phase close to lithium metal surface. Therefore, a deeper understanding of how liquid alloy facilitate the electrochemical performance of lithium metal battery is urgently required.

Herein, a gradient SEI which is composed of flexible surface-rich polycarbonate moieties and low Li+ partial molar volume inorganic LiF-rich inside is designed by applying liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive. Initially, the calculation verified that liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive would facilitate the formation of the gradient SEI layer. In the Li||Li half‐cell test, we successfully achieved dense deposition of Li metal and in this way, the cycling performance with liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive is greatly improved especially at high rate (10 mA cm−2). Voltage polarization was greatly reduced and long cycle life are achieved due to the gradient SEI layer achieved in the interface of Li anode and electrolyte. In the Li||LFP cell, high coulombic efficiency at long cycle life of over 2500 cycles are achieved with the liquid alloy GaSnIn as electrolyte additive.

To gain the molecular insights into the stability of each component in the electrolyte, we first investigated the different molecular structure and the corresponding relative energy of EC, DMC, PF6 –, and EC-PF6 – by first-principles calculation in Fig. 1b. The grid data of the charge results obtained from the predicted by M062x via gaussian calculations package are shown in the form of electrostatic potential (ESP) isosurface on the molecules, which provide brief knowledge of the active sites and chemical reactivity. The distribution of the electronic charge around a molecule or the chemical species is commonly termed the electrostatic potential and is expressed by the following equation:

where the ZA is the charge on nucleus A located at RA, and

is the electronic density function of the molecule. A positive ESP reflects relative affinities for the nuclephiles, elsewise the negative region indicates the affinities for the electrophiles. For the EC and DEC electrolyte molecules, the top oxygen and bridging oxygen show relatively negative ESP, which indicates these oxygen sites are highly affiliative to the Li atoms [29]. The configuration of PF6 – anions has previously been shown to be the most stable, which agree well with our report and the solvents of the carbonate electrolyte, EC, and DMC, also show good stability against decomposition [30]. However, the ion pairs formed by PF6 – anions and EC/DMC solvent show much decreased stability, evidenced by the largely declined LUMO and HOMO energy gaps. Interestingly, EC-DMC-PF6 – pairs is slightly more stable than that of DMC-PF6 – pairs (Table S1). To further investigate the decomposition process of ion-solvent pairs and the composition of the SEI layer in the surface of liquid alloyed lithium and pristine lithium, we carried out the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations in Fig. 1a. First, the ion pairs of PF6 –, EC, and DMC molecules were placed on the interface between electrolyte and Li metal (001)/liquid-alloyed Li metal (001). In the pristine lithium metal surface, EC molecules have a tendency to move towards the surface of lithium metal, suggesting the strong combination of EC molecules with lithium atoms. After cycling for 120, 360, 780, 1270, and 3500 fs, the decomposition of EC and the formation of C2H4 are observed initially, following the decomposition reaction [31]:

Subsequently, PF6 – anion is closely coordinated with lithium surface, leading to the decomposition of PF6 – anion and the formation of LiF on the lithium metal surface. On the contrast, on the surface of liquid alloyed lithium metal surface, PF6 – anion instead of EC molecules would move towards the liquid alloyed lithium metal surface and follow the reaction [32]:
LiPF6 ↔ PF5 + LiF

In this way, a high-purity LiF inner SEI layer is yielded. The generated PF5 would induce the polymerization of EC solvents, facilitating the formation of polycarbonate species. In this way, a gradient, heterogeneous, mixed organic and inorganic SEI with large separate domains is formed. Thus, a uniform LiF-rich SEI layer close to the lithium metal is expected to form during plating while organic components composing of flexible polycarbonate species form near the far end of the lithium metal surface, unlike the homogeneously mixed organicinorganic composition of a traditional SEI [33]. We further investigate the electron localization function (ELF) of the clean Li (001) surface and Ga containing Li metal surface as shown in Fig. 1c and d, respectively [34]. The ELF provides a measurement of the electron localization that occurs in 3-dimensional space, which can be used to visualize the bond type and order present, with higher values in red representing highly localized electrons, through to blue indicating a lower probability of electron localization (scale between 0 and 1). In lithium metal surface, free electrons are homogeneously distributed and the work function is only 2.8 eV, suggesting the transfer of free electron is easily attracted by the electron-withdrawing group such as carbonyl group in EC molecule, leading to the reduction of EC molecules. On the contrast, on the liquid alloyed lithium metal surface, the free electrons in the lithium metal surface is trapped by the liquid alloyed atom in the 3 bottom layers of lithium. In this way, the work function of liquid alloyed lithium metal surface is increased to 3.1 eV, suggesting the higher energy barrier of free electron transport as well as weaker reduction of electron-withdrawing molecules. Although SEI cracks may happen during cycling, the preferential reduction of LiPF6 can promote the rich LiF in the SEI layer near to lithium metal side, and the high molecular weight polycarbonate moieties in the outer surface to adjust the volume changes, thus effectively suppressing the crack deterioration [22]. The initial decomposition of LiPF6 would lead to the formation of strong Lewis acids PF5 derived from the additive level of LiPF6 and induces the polymerization of EC solvents, facilitating the formation of polycarbonate species [35]. The SEI layer in the surface would be enriched with polycarbonate constituents, which could effectively protect the electrode from the attack by the electrolyte [36]. In addition, the polycarbonate moieties on the surface with relatively high molecular weights would act as flexible polymer binder to hold other ionically conductive SEI components. On the other hand, the SEI layer inside is rich in the ceramic LiF, and would realize the efficient dendrite suppressing function.

The as-received liquid alloy GaSnIn shows sphere morphology and high phase purity (Figs. S2–S4). The fundamental lithium nucleation and growth behaviors in different electrolytes during lithium deposition process were studied based on the nucleation overpotential (μn) and the plateau overpotential (μp), which are the reflection of the energy barrier of nucleation process and mass-transfer process, respectively [37,38]. Fig. 2a and b shows that Li||Li cell with pristine commercial GaSnIn-free electrolyte shows similar μp (0.056 V) while a much higher μn (0.021 V) values when compared with commercial GaSnIn-free electrolyte with the addition of liquid alloy (μn = 0.011 V and μp = 0.056 V). The greatly reduced nucleation overpotential suggests the much lower energy barrier of Li nucleation, which would facilitate the electrochemical performance of LMBs. We further investigated the rate capability of the carbonate electrolyte with the addition of liquid alloy and the carbonate electrolyte with the addition of liquid alloy is able to survive at ultrahigh current density of 10.0 mA cm−2, with a smooth voltage plateau with an overvoltage of only 0.15 V, as depicted in Fig. 2c. On the contrast, the pristine electrolyte is unable to survive even at 5.0 mA cm−2. Furthermore, the long-term cycling stability of symmetrical Li||Li cells was investigated. As shown in Fig. 2d and e, symmetrical Li||Li electrodes with the GaSnIn containing electrolyte is able to survive for 550 and 1500 h at 1.0 and 5.0 mA cm−2, respectively, at a fixed capacity of 1 mAh cm−2, demonstrating stable Li metal stripping/plating performance, with mere increase in the polarization. On the contrast, symmetrical Li||Li electrodes in the GaSnIn-free electrolyte have obvious fluctuations in voltages caused by the ever-changing and increasing interfaces of the Li metal and electrolyte. At rather low current of 1.0 mA cm−2, the symmetrical Li||Li cells become short-circulated after only 240 h, suggesting severe lithium dendrite growth. On the contrast, at a high-current rate (5.0 mA cm−2), the polarization of the GaSnIn-free electrolyte is much greater than that of the GaSnIn electrolyte after cycling, due to Li dendrite growth and dead Li formation in the repeated plating/stripping process.

To obtain further insight, the morphologies of Li metal anodes after cycling is investigated through ex-situ SEM. There are obvious differences on the cycled Li metal, in different electrolyte. The corrosion depths of lithium metal anode at different cycling number is shown in Fig. 3a–h. After first cycle, the thicknesses of the corrosion layer are similar for both pristine electrolyte and electrolyte with liquid alloy additive. However, after 10 h of cycling, the thickness of the corrosion layer in pristine electrolyte is slightly thicker than that in electrolyte with liquid alloy additive and the difference becomes much greater after 100 and 250 h of cycling. The corrosion layer of the lithium metal after 250 h reaches maximum of 582 µm, which may be the reason for the failure of the cell in pristine electrolyte. This surface layer sits pretty loosely on the top of bulk Li, which is believed to be able to be detached easily from the bulk Li.

To further shed light on the optimizing strategy of the liquid alloy additive in the electrolyte, the top view SEM images of Li metal in electrolyte with and without GaSnIn electrolyte additive after 50 cycles were shown in Fig. 3i and j. A dendrite-like surface with obvious wire morphology is observed on lithium anode in the pristine LiPF6-EC/DMC electrolyte (Fig. 3i). It is believed that the porous and loose structures would greatly increase the contact area between the lithium metal and electrolyte. The larger contact area would exacerbate the side reaction between electrolyte and electrode and continuously consume the limited electrolyte. In this way, large surface area massy Li dendrites are formed, leading to the dendrite growth towards cathode and finally short-circuit due to or the dry-up of electrolyte and large resistance in the battery, both of which finally lead to the termination of cells. In contrast, with the presence of liquid alloy GaSnIn, the surface of Li metal shows smooth and compact morphology with no obvious dendrites formation (Fig. 3j), confirming that the liquid alloy GaSnIn electrolyte additive would suppress the growth of Li dendrites. Additionally, electrochemical impedance (EIS) spectroscopy in Fig. 3k and l for the Li||Li cells at 1.0 mA cm−2 was conducted before and after 80 cycles. Before cycling, the cells in the GaSnIn electrolyte exhibits the same charge transfer resistance as well as Li ion diffusion resistance compared with the pristine electrolyte [39], while after long-term cycling, the impedances of GaSnIn-free electrolyte fluctuate largely, thus demonstrating stable interfacial impedance induced by the GaSnIn-containing electrolyte, which also suggest the efficient dendrite suppressing capability.

To investigate the SEI structure of Li metal after deposition in electrolyte with and without GaSnIn, we conducted XPS analyses on Li metal anode surfaces after 100 cycles in the carbonate electrolyte in Fig. 4 and Figs. S5–S7. The etching rate of the monatomic Ar ion gun is 0.83 nm/min and thus, the corresponding etching depths are 0, 4.15, and 12.45 nm, for etching times of 1, 5, and 15 min, respectively. Fig. 4 shows high-resolution F 1 s, Ga 3d, C 1s, and Li 1s XPS spectra of the SEI of the Li metal anode after cycling in electrolyte with GaSnIn, which represents typical components derived from a carbonate-based electrolyte. XPS depth profiling was employed to investigate the different Li chemical environments from the top surface of the SEI layer to the Li surface underneath. The C 1s peaks of the surface areas can be decomposed into five main peaks at 284.8, 285.3, 287.4, 288.5, and 291.2 eV, which are related to the CH, CC, CO, CO3 2–, and polycarbonate groups, respectively (Fig. 4c), suggesting the co-existence of organic and inorganic products. The surface layer of the SEI layer shows rich in LixPFy, while the inner layer rich in LiF, which is confirmed the priority consumption of LiPF6 and consensus with the calculation in Fig. 1d. The C 1s spectrum confirmed that the surface is rich in polycarbonate, which is consensus with the results of AIMD predicted in Fig. 1a. This is also confirmed by the XPS Li 1s spectrum. The surface is rich in LiF, with substantial amount of Li2CO3, while the inner layer is still mainly composed of LiF, but only mere amount of Li2CO3. On the contrast, the XPS results show that the GaSnIn electrolyte additive would promote the generation of a gradient SEI film and the gradient SEI lay composed of flexible surface-rich polycarbonate moieties and low Li+ partial molar volume inorganic LiF-rich core shows excellent dendrite suppressing characteristics. In detail, the weak bonding of the inner LiF-rich SEI to Li can effectively facilitate the lateral diffusion of lithium metal and thus prevent Li dendrite from breaking the SEI layer, while the outer flexible polycarbonate-rich SEI layer act in the role of polymer binder to ensure the integrity of the other ionically conductive SEI components together and intimately stick to the bulk Li metal anode.

In Fig. 5, the electrochemical performance of Li||LFP at a high areal capacity (3 mAh cm−2) at 1C (1C = 170 mAh/g) is presented at the voltage range of 2.0–4.0 V. The mass loading of LFP cathode is ~25 mg cm−2 to ensure the areal capacity is up to 3 mAh cm−2. In the carbonate electrolyte with GaSnIn additive, the battery delivers capacity fading of 0.011% per cycle after 2500 cycles and a stable charging/discharging voltage plateau. More importantly, the average coulombic efficiency is maintained at 99.06%, demonstrating a superior performance and limited SEI layer as well as active lithium consumption over the control cells. On the contrast, the cell with standard carbonate electrolyte can only run 70 cycles at 1C and after 70 cycles, the capacity quickly degrades to below 40 mAh/g. The detailed charging/discharging voltage profile of Li||LFP full cell in the electrolyte with GaSnIn additive reveals that the areal capacity can reach 3 mAh cm−2 with an overpotential of 80 mV. On the contrast, the cell with standard carbonate electrolyte deliver a rather large overpotential of 180 mV and relative fast capacity fading.

We have successfully created a gradient SEI layer combining the advantages of flexible polymer and high touristy ceramic, through liquid alloy electrolyte additive. The gradient SEI layer is composed of surface-rich polycarbonate, as flexible polymer matrix shell to accommodate the volume changes, and low Li+ partial molar volume LiF-rich core for dendrite suppression, which was confirmed experimentally and theoretically. In this way, the liquid alloy electrolyte additive enabled dendrite-suppression during repeated Li plating/stripping for long period (1500 h) at ultrahigh rate of 5 mA cm−2 in symmetrical batteries. Moreover, as a demonstration, the Li||LFP full cells with liquid alloy additive show excellent average coulombic efficiency of over 99.06% for over 2500 cycles at high areal capacity of 3 mAh/cm2. These results deepen our understanding on liquid alloy as a promising electrolyte additive for efficient dendrite suppressing, enabling the practical lithium metal batteries.

Weina Xu: Writing - original draft; Writing - review & editing, Data Curation, Methodology, Validation, Visualization, Investigation. Xiaobin Liao: Data curation, Formal analysis, Investigation, Writing - review & editing. Congli Sun: Methodology, Resources, Visualization. Wangwang Xu: Resources, Funding acquisition. Kangning Zhao: Conceptualization, Data curation, Conceptualization, Writing - original draft, Writing - review & editing, Funding acquisition. Yan Zhao: Data curation, Resources.
